description: From Middle English aferen (“to frighten, terrify”), from Old English āfǣran (“to terrify, dismay”), from ā- (perfective prefix) + fǣran (“to frighten; to devour, raven”), from fǣr (“sudden danger, calamity, ambush; a blitz”), from Proto-Germanic *fērō (“danger”), from Proto-Indo-European *per- (“to try, dare, risk”).

verbs.description: afear (third-person singular simple present afears, present participle afearing, simple past and past participle afeared)

entries.meaning: (obsolete or dialectal) To imbue with fear; to affright, to terrify.
